content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table, with 4 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in minutes,” and the heading for row 2 is “H of t, in degrees Celsius.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. H of t is 90. Column 2. t is 3. H of t is 80. Column 3. t is 8. H of t is 67. Column 4. t is 12. H of t is 58."><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="10em 0.05em 3em 3em 3em 3em" equalrows="true" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0.5ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="1ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(minutes)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>12</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mi>H</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(degrees Celsius)</mtext></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>90</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>80</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>67</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>58</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> As a bowl of soup cools, the temperature of the soup is given by the twice-differentiable function <math alttext="H"><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 12"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="H of t "><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in degrees Celsius (<math alttext="degrees Celsius"><mstyle><mrow><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) and time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in minutes. Values of <math alttext="H of t "><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at selected values of time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. (a) Use the data in the table to approximate <math alttext="H prime of 5"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer. Using correct units, explain the meaning of <math alttext="H prime of 5"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

frqParts.text: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION. You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table, with 4 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in minutes,” and the heading for row 2 is “H of t, in degrees Celsius.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. H of t is 90. Column 2. t is 3. H of t is 80. Column 3. t is 8. H of t is 67. Column 4. t is 12. H of t is 58."><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="10em 0.05em 3em 3em 3em 3em" equalrows="true" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0.5ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="1ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(minutes)</mtext></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>12</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mi>H</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.45em"></mspace><mtext>(degrees Celsius)</mtext></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>90</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>80</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>67</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>58</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math> As a bowl of soup cools, the temperature of the soup is given by the twice-differentiable function <math alttext="H"><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 12"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="H of t "><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in degrees Celsius (<math alttext="degrees Celsius"><mstyle><mrow><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) and time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in minutes. Values of <math alttext="H of t "><mstyle><mrow><mi>H</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at selected values of time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. (a) Use the data in the table to approximate <math alttext="H prime of 5"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Show the computations that lead to your answer. Using correct units, explain the meaning of <math alttext="H prime of 5"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

(b) Is there a time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 12"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, at which the temperature of the soup is <math alttext="60 degrees Celsius "><mstyle><mrow><mn>60</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

(c) The temperature of the soup is also modeled by the twice-differentiable function <math alttext="C"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 12"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="C of t "><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in degrees Celsius and time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in minutes. It is known that <math alttext="C of 3, equals 80 "><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>80</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and the derivative of <math alttext="C"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is given by <math alttext="C prime of t, equals, negative 3.6 times e raised to the negative 0.05, t power. "><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3.6</mn></mrow><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.05</mn><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="C"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="t equals 3 "><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and use it to approximate <math alttext="C of 5"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Based on the model given in part (c), at what rate, in degrees Celsius per minute per minute, is the rate of change of the temperature of the soup changing at time <math alttext="t equals 3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes?

topic.text: 1.16: Working with the Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT)

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
